body: dev syncup conclusion: we should maintain old groupId for core extensions and it is ok to change same for contributed extensions. this will be backported to 0.9.0 so that users dont have build breaking change in 0.9.1 .
given that sync-up conclusion applies to this PR, so :+1:
pls squash/cleanup your commits

@himanshug @drcrallen  this will require backporting rocketmq and a few other PRs as well

thoughts?
@b-slim , ok, i will add these.
@fjy which PRs? porting this structure change to 0.9.0 shouldn't require including the new extensions, those just need to be cut out of the patch when it is ported.
@gianm okay makes sense
@drcrallen @himanshug @gianm i think this is ready
@himanshug this has merge conflicts
closing this for now, will revisit if/when needed.
This is great
removed option
@fjy thanks please look at https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2578
Will be fixed by https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2578
Though, you might want to only do one of them eagerly...
:+1: after travis
@gianm can you do the backport?
@drcrallen yes I will backport after this is in master.
:+1:  it would be nice to have an UT that verifies that each instance of RealtimeTuningConfig has unique base persist directory.
@himanshug added UT
cool :+1: , let us merge after travis is done.
@himanshug can we add some docs about it ?

I'm :+1: on this as is.  As a bit of a riff on it, I think we could also add a config parameter which is the maximum allowable maxRows.  I.e. change the lines to essentially

```
Math.min(query.getContextValue(CTX_KEY_MAX_RESULTS, config.getMaxResults()), config.getMaxAllowableResults);
```

?

@nicktylah is there any reason why region needs to be part of the autoscaler config? I can't really think of a reason why someone would want to run the overlord in a different region than the middlemanagers.
In my opinion it would be much simpler to set the region in the runtime properties along with other aws settings and have the autoscaler use the same region as everything else. Please correct me if I am not unerstanding your use-case well.
Good, what about also allow groupBy maxIntermediateRows limit be overridable by context?
@drcrallen oh right we added that, yeah, segmentAndCache is cool
I agree /w @binlijin it'd be nice to also be able to override that

@xvrl The problem I'm running into is that the aws sdk sets a default region of `us-west-1` if nothing is specified. All my instances run in `us-west-2`, so I get this error in my overlord logs:

```
2016-03-03T04:26:08,645 ERROR [ScalingExec--0] io.druid.indexing.overlord.autoscaling.ec2.EC2AutoScaler - Unable to provision any EC2 instances.
com.amazonaws.AmazonServiceException: Invalid availability zone: [us-west-2b] (Service: AmazonEC2; Status Code: 400; Error Code: InvalidParameterValue; Request ID: f0fdb737-f035-463f-8c05-e78e40a048c6)
```

According to the aws docs, 

> Note
> The AWS SDK for Java uses us-east-1 as the default region if you do not specify a region in your code. However, the AWS Management Console uses us-west-2 as its default. Therefore, when using the AWS Management Console in conjunction with your development, be sure to specify the same region in both your code and the console.
This looks very useful.
:+1: after https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2579/files#r54838142 is resolved

@himanshug, thanks,  See https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/druid-development/GXRpXfBzfJs, we do some optimization on daily exact uniques count, and need maxIntermediateRows >= maxRows when use group by query.

About the UT.
I could not use `testQueryCaching()`. The reason is that it can only verify mocked results by the same mocked results using `SeverExpectation`. The situation where expecting and mocking results are mixed up implies someone can not add extra expecting results besides mocking ones. I tried to come up with a workaround but it was not easy.
So, I decided to make a simple test case building the context, which omits some features like testing under randomness and test the function with incrementally expanding intervals.
resolve merge conflicts and rebase it.
resolve merge conflicts and rebase it
@gianm @drcrallen: Since its mostly related to your changes, please have a look at it.

@CHOIJAEHONG1 I believe this feature should have a query context flag and be disabled by default, otherwise it might confuse existing users that do not expect any results when there is no data.

Also, it should be noted that zero may or may not be the appropriate result depending on the aggregator. We should make sure it does not break any post-aggregations, especially ones that convert complex types into numbers, since zero may not be a valid results for those.
@CHOIJAEHONG1 I believe we should add a query context flag to explicitly enable filling or not.
This doesn't feel right. After this the msg offset will be wrong since there was a message that was dropped which could have been a valid message and just had a transfer corruption of some kind.
i am not sure you are referring to which offset, but that's how you can skip it and then kafka retention rule will evict the event.
It would be good to retry a few times before giving up on the message, as I believe @drcrallen is right that the message could just have been corrupted in transit.
@gianm can you develop more about retry few times ? in that case we need a strategy with backoff maybe ? can you explain it more ?

I think some backing off would work yeah. This should be a really very rare occurrence so I don't think we need anything fancy. Possibly just a RetryUtils.retry with a "shouldRetry" that does an instanceof check on the exception.

Would be good to confirm that actually can work though. When you get one of these CRC exceptions on `iter.next().message()`, what happens if you call that again? Does it try to get the same message? Does it go to the next one?

If it doesn't actually try to re-get it from the server, then we might have to reconnect the consumer to get that to work.

I think the overhead of that is ok given that this should happen very rarely.
There number of segments to load seems to revolve around 30 going up and down.

@gianm the actual consumer API doesn't allow us to manage the offset, i don't see how this can be done without moving to another consumer API.
when you call `iter.next().message()` it does increment the offset and you can not rewind it thought.
ok, if it's not feasible to do this in a nicer way, I think your way is fine. We should eventually be pushing people that do care about correctness into a different system once it exists.
@gianm can you plus one it in that case ? this is causing our ingestion pipeline to totally shutdown.

sure, but could you please include a comment describing the potential pitfall here? (erroneously dropping a message that was fine on the broker but corrupted in transit)

:+1: with that comment.

@gianm i am ok with adding the comment, but i thought once you call `next()` it is impossible to read it again from the actual consumer. The only way to do it is to have another consumer group thought. i am i missing something ?
@b-slim because you're not committing the offset, the kafka consumer would try to read it again if you shutdown the consumer and then re-start it (as it resumes from previously committed offsets)
@gianm done !

A few questions:
- Is there any risk of a flood of corrupt CRCs and flooding the log?
- Is there a place we can document this "new" behavior of dropping events?
- Can you please tag this with label/milestone appropriately
@navis is this dependent on @himanshug 's arithmetic PR? If so can you comment as such in the master comment?
@navis in trying to hit the "count == 0" case, can you think of a code path that would hit that case?

Updated the top comment with some more details and a couple of discussion items I'd like feedback on.

Also removed the [wip] tag as the TODOs are resolved and things work to the best of my knowledge. We have started running this in our cluster yesterday and are keeping an eye on that for how well it's working (looks ok so far)
@drcrallen No, It's not using arithmetic PR of @himanshug. And in current druid, it seemed not possible to make count == 0 case in real environment. Should we throw exception or something?
The json thing is my fault ... It doesn't get indexed if it is not EOL separated objects....
depends on https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2588

@xvrl I think the same way about handling complex types and others. It looks hard to fill empty values of complex columns especially when we use a javascript aggregator because the broker does not know what the type of argument is in a javascript function. Although the broker gets the type information by `AggregatorFactory.getTypeName()`, it is not a actual type of column to be accssed. A javascript aggregators returns `float` as its type name;

How about showing only timestamp without any values for empty buckets like the below?

```
{
  "timestamp" : "2013-09-04T23:00:00.000Z",
  "result" : {
    "langHyperUnique" : 0,
    "longMin" : null,
    "longSsum" : null,
    "count" : null,
    "sum(strlen(language))" : null,
    "sum(log(added))" : null,
    "uniqLang" : 0,
    "longMax" : null
  }
```

By the way, as-is `skipEmptyBuckets` works this way. The first is empty one. `longMin` shows `9223372036854775807` and `longMax` is `-9223372036854775808` which dosen't seem to be good in some cases(I am not sure). Do you think this should be improved?

```
{
  "timestamp" : "2013-08-31T10:00:00.000Z",
  "result" : {
    "langHyperUnique" : 0.0,
    "longMin" : 9223372036854775807,
    "count" : 0,
    "longSum" : 0,
    "sum(strlen(language))" : 10.0,
    "sum(log(added))" : 10.0,
    "uniqLang" : 0.0,
    "longMax" : -9223372036854775808
  }
}, {
  "timestamp" : "2013-08-31T11:00:00.000Z",
  "result" : {
    "langHyperUnique" : 1.0002442201269182,
    "longMin" : 905,
    "count" : 1,
    "longSsum" : 1,
    "sum(strlen(language))" : 12.0,
    "sum(log(added))" : 16.807934943699927,
    "uniqLang" : 1.0002442201269182,
    "longMax" : 905
  }
}
```

query

```
{
  "queryType": "timeseries",
  "dataSource": "wikipedia",
  "intervals": [ "2013-08-28/2013-09-05" ],
  "granularity": "hour",
  "aggregations": [
     {"type": "count", "name" : "count"},
     {"type": "longSum", "fieldName": "count", "name": "longSsum"},
     {"type": "longMin", "fieldName": "added", "name": "longMin"},
     {"type": "longMax", "fieldName": "added", "name": "longMax"},
     {"type": "javascript", "name": "sum(log(added))",
                "fieldNames" : ["added"],
                "fnAggregate" : "function(current, a) { return current + Math.log(a); }",
                "fnCombine" : "function(partialA, partialB) { return partialA + partialB; }",
                "fnReset" : "function() { return 10; }"},
     {"type": "javascript", "name": "sum(strlen(language))",
                "fieldNames" : ["language"],
                "fnAggregate" : "function(current, a) { return current + a.length; }",
                "fnCombine" : "function(partialA, partialB) { return partialA + partialB; }",
                "fnReset" : "function() { return 10; }"},
    {"type": "cardinality", "name" : "uniqLang", "fieldNames" : ["language"] },
    {"type": "hyperUnique", "name" : "langHyperUnique", "fieldName" : "langHyperUnique" }
  ],
  "context": {
    "skipEmptyBuckets": "false",
    "uncoveredIntervalsLimit": 100,
    "useCache" : "false",
    "populateCache" : "false"
  }
}
```

@drcrallen dropping events, it is something impossible to avoid at realtime pipeline, that's why you want to have replicas.
I have added docs.

@navis since there isn't an obviously good solution for how to handle variance with count == 0, how about throwing an ISE and mentioning in the code that it shouldn't happen, and the correct behavior is not terribly obvious.

@navis can you refactor it a bit somehow so that the code for the sum, count, variance streaming update is in one place, and the code for merging streamed updates is in one place? There should hopefully only need to be two methods instead of having a few of them scattered about.
@drcrallen any other blocker ? i have addressed all the points.

I still have a question of `Is there any risk of a flood of corrupt CRCs and flooding the log?` if the answer is "no, CRC errors are expected to be transient and per-message" rather than per-connection, then I'm :+1:  but please answer that issue.
@drcrallen According to the case we faced it was per message.

Yes it is per message... my question is still:

Is there any risk of flooding the log?

@drcrallen what do you call flooding ? what is a risk ? this question is not clear. The current implementation will log every corrupt event. Either way if it is the case you want to know about it and if all the message are corrupt you need to fix the root cause.

spoke with @gianm about this, and the impression I'm getting is that multiple CRC errors in a row _should_ only result from some deep hardware failure, and in such a case log spam is probably the least of your concerns as the node may be unrecoverable.

@himanshug I don't have a good way to test the pom changes on the hdfs extension, are you guys able to do that?
Haven't had a chance to read this yet, but I did try it on our cluster with EMR and the Hadoop index task still worked. Didn't try HDFS deep storage.
@himanshug could you include a test? It should be possible to add one in RealtimeIndexTaskTest, as that already has some tests for handoff.
@gianm addressed all comments and added test for handoff timeout.
Wouldn't it be possible to have the map task do a rollup on its data? This way a lot less data will hit the reducer.

Ah, that is already an option, you can try that to see if it's enough for your dataset. I guess it depends on how much data you're sending through each mapper. You can turn that on by setting useCombiner to true in your tuningConfig.

@mmcgowan you mentioned that you have build a Datadog Druid extension.
This sounds very interesting. I searched for it but couldn't find anything.
Can you tell me anything about it? Is it open-source?
thanks
Sascha
:+1: after travis
@erikdubbelboer  @gianm I believe "useCombiner" should be able to handle this. ( doc http://druid.io/docs/0.8.3/ingestion/batch-ingestion.html )

FYI, I did a lot of dependency resolution to get 0.9.0 to work with some of our extensions. The results can be found here: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2596

This might affect how this extension manages exclusions. Hopefully the information in the PR (and expanded documentation in the PR) helps.

@drcrallen we actually do not depend upon pull-deps for hadoop jars as our hadoop is customized including the client jars, none of them are downloaded from maven but present in some of the internal places on the network.

you can test it with open source versions of hadoop (cloudera, hortonworks, direct stable release off apache) that community would use.
@himanshug ok cool as long as this isn't going to screw up your guys stuff
@himanshug It did, as I wrote in [https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/druid-user/TvwIBUEzqwM](druid-user/TvwIBUEzqwM) it made things much much faster and better.
